content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not too simple, I had to think about what best of three meant for a bit. Still easy enough to solve quickly. Nice

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I think the general idea is good but there isn't any explanation regarding how to determine who won, why do you need 2 sets for example? just for the draw? I don't like the idea of having 2 different sets just for the draw option while there is no draw in the test cases, so I have to reject it.
Sorry.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's clear! I enjoyed solving it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash! Interesting to see how the last winner is always the overall winner!

I've checked that with these test cases, a set is considered won after a player reaches 2 points, not after three games with possible tie-breakers (like I expected at first).
Example: last validator with 0 0 1 1 0 1 ... if considering sets with 3 games, player 1 would have win the first set with 1 win and 2 draws, and the second set with 2 wins and 1 draw, meaning player 1 should have win the championship

I'm not sure if how to handle ties is common knowledge, given my and Frontier's confusion with the first test case. If I understand correctly, the three sets are:
1 2 1 => #1 wins
0 2 2 1 => #2 wins
2 1 1 => #1 wins
#1 wins 2-1

I was able to figure it out after seeing that Test case #2 has only 5 inputs instead of the naively-expected 9. Consider swapping these two cases, and remove tie games from the Test #2 validator.

Close Call looks correct to me. Close Call #2 should have a lot more tie games so that it looks more like its validator.

EDIT: Ignore the following
And finally, as Frontier also mentioned, it's a silly coincidence that the final winner of a game is also the winner of the match. Should be an easy  but necessary fix.

Hi, I'm a bit confused on how the game results are laid out.

For example, Test 2-1, from my understanding, player 1 has already won the game after the first 9 games. Why would there be a 10th game?

I'm also not getting why the last game winner will always be the winner of the match, according to the smart solution.
In Validator Close Call, it seems to be a draw or a incomplete game, if I understood correctly.
I like it, its original and easy but please delete the duplicate
Hey, this is my first contribution so any feedback is welcome!
Oops, I think I submitted it twice. Deleted the duplicate now, thanks!

Oops, looks like Test 2-1 was a bit wrong. The match is supposed to end exactly when a player has won, not before or after. I fixed it the test case.

For the validator close call, I can't see what's wrong. You mean this one: "2 2 2 1 1 1 2 1" or?

Thanks for the feedback!

I swapped the test cases, added some more draws to Close Call #2 and also added an example in the statement to hopefully make it more clear. I also included a draw in this example to show have draws are handled.

Checked it and it seems nice. About that coincidence, I don't think it is necessary to "fix" it. I think it is a nice reward for whomever quickly finds it out, a valid way to differentiate both speed and code size.

My first thought is that you brought up a cool point, but since coders won't be able to see the validators to confirm this exploit anyway, it's an invalid point.

My second thought (or rather, after thinking about the problem for some time) is that... isn't it impossible for the winner of the final game to not be the winner of the match? So yes, you brought up a cool point again :P

Yes, I meant the "2 2 2 1 1 1 2 1".

I just realised its my misunderstanding,
I was thinking it as the following
Set 1: 2 2 2, therefore winner is player 2
Set 2: 1 1 1, therefore winner is player 1
Set 3: 2 1, therefore it's a draw or incomplete?

Now i realised it should be the following
Set 1: 2 2, therefore winner is player 2
Set 2: 2 1 1, therefore winner is player 1
Set 3: 1 2 1, therefore winner is player 1

Now that I can see how the sequence work, I can understand why the last winner will always be the overall winner.

Might be a good idea, to add in how a game would not end in a draw within a set.

Also, although you have wrote its best out of three out of three, somehow it still went over my head, that a set may end in 2 games. Not sure if its just me though.

I think this would be interesting to solve if the statement can be somewhat more informative.
Ah, I see. Thanks for the explanation. I added some more info in the statement to clarify. What do you think?
I think it's clearer now. Upvoted!
